question: Mornin', Ray. Whaddya know whaddya say? Me and Sandra caught "The African Queen" at the Chinese last night. Great picture, great picture. What's with this "Mr. Appleton" crap? Your boss hiding in there? What's that mean? Louise... what gives? Sort what out? Are my pages done? They took 'em? Who took 'em? Louise, what's going on... Leo... what's going on?
answer: Peter, their hands are tied. You see that, don't you?

question: I... I don't believe this.
answer: Are you saying it's a mistake, that you didn't go to any meetings? They say you did.

question: Who the hell is this "they?"
answer: Congress, the FBI, Red Channels, it don't matter who the hell "they" is. "They" know who "they" are, that's all that matters. Now, did you go to any meetings?

question: No. Yeah... I... I don't know. Maybe I did. Leo, this was before Pearl Harbor. I was in college. It was a bunch of kids, and I was just one of 'em. I didn't believe in what they were saying. Hell, I didn't even know what they were saying!
answer: So, you're saying that it's true. You went to a meeting of a known communist organization.

question: Leo, I was trying to impress a skirt. You know me, I'm non- political. Republican, Democrat, Communist, there's not a dime's worth of difference between 'em anyway.
answer: You should watch what you say.

question: I don't know who fingered me, but I'm not a communist!
answer: Kid, that cuts no ice with them.

question: What? That I'm accused of being a communist when I don't happen to be one?
answer: They know you were at that meeting, Peter. They've been told, and they know.

question: Leo, you're my agent. Tell "them" to take a flyin' piss. I didn't do anything wrong. I fought in the war, for crissakes!
answer: Fought? Come on, Pete, you ran the PX at Fort Dix.

question: I was decorated.
answer: I know. A Purple Heart.

question: Exactly.
answer: You broke your arm. You were coming out of a bar. You were drunk.

question: At least I was on our side! Look, they want me to testify? I'll testify. I'll tell 'em anything they want to hear! Jesus, Leo, this is my career!
answer: You can't testify.

question: Why not?
answer: Don't take this personally, kid. If it were up to me, I'd have you testify wearing your uniform and your medal, wrapped in a flag with one hand on your heart and the other hand on a bible. What can I say? I like you. They don't want you to testify because you're not a big enough fish for them. They just don't want you writing pictures for now. That's all.

question: Yeah, well, that's enough.
answer: Peter, I believe in you. More to the point, I read your new script... um...

question: "Ashes To Ashes?"
answer: That's the one, "Ashes To Ashes." I think it's great. But it'll never get made with this communist business hanging over your head. You can't work until you're cleared -- and believe me, starting right now, I'm gonna do everything I can to make that happen.

question: So, it is a blacklist.
answer: Don't say that. There is no such thing as a blacklist. Now, are you gonna play ball?

question: Yes. Leo, goddammit... this isn't fair!
answer: Kid, this is the United States Government we're talkin' about. Fair ain't the point.

question: Huh. Red...
answer: Pete? Pete...? Oh, Pete... What happened?

question: What exactly did you hear?
answer: That you got let go.

question: I wasn't alone. Wasn't Frankie Ruskin directing the picture you're in?
answer: He was, but he got sick. We got a new director today. Why?

question: Well, whatever Frankie's got, it's catching.
answer: You mean, he was... let go, too?

question: They're saying I'm a communist, Sandy. But I'm not, you know that. I'm gonna fight 'em, and I'm gonna win, but I'll need your help. A lot of good people are being accused of things they didn't do. Hell, even if I was a communist, this is America, goddammit, a person should be able to be whatever they want to be! Right?
answer: Of course, but I... I don't know how I... how much help I can be to you. This is the sort of thing... someone saying you're a communist... it can ruin your career.

question: Will you help me, Sandy?
answer: I'll have to think about this. I have to get back... I should go...

question: So nice to be a pariah.
answer: Pete. You think maybe you've had enough?

question: Bought the bottle, didn't I? To the United States of America. Long my she wave. Thanks, Jerry. Tell me something.
answer: What.

question: You tight with J. Edgar Hoover?
answer: The G-man?

question: Zackly.
answer: Pete, if J. Edgar Hoover walked in here wearing a dress, I wouldn't know him.

question: Too bad. He says I'm a communist.
answer: You should watch what you say. You don't know who's listening.

question: You know I'm not a communist, don't you, Jer?
answer: Sure, I suppose. That why you're on a bender?

question: This is not a bender yet. This is the start of a bender. But I can see how you were confused, they look a lot alike.
answer: Pete... go home. Come on, I'll call that girlfriend of yours, what's her name... Sandy?

question: Sandra Sinclair.
answer: Gimmee her number, I'll have her pick you up.

question: Sandra Sinclair. Wanna know her real name? Bella Iskowitz. No one's who they really are, Jer. Everyone's someone else. Even you. Even me. Especially me. I'm Peter Appleton, the communist who's not really a communist.
answer: I wanna close up soon. C'mon, let's call her.

question: Nope. Can't. We're through.
answer: Then I'll call you a cab.

question: I'll save you the trouble. I'm a cab. There. Did it myself. 'Sides, car's right outside. I'll be seein' ya, Jer.
answer: Pete...

question: Drive. Drive. Bad idea. Too drunk to drive. One-thirty. Huh! Early. Can't go home yet. Oops. Huh? Whatsa...
answer: I had no idea how I got to Santa Monica, but it certainly was a good idea. I don't think I could've faced the headache I had alone in my apartment. At least I had the ocean air. Three forty-five. I had only been there for a couple of hours at most. Truth be told, I was still fairly drunk. I'd head north until the sun came up or I ran out of gas, whichever came first.

question: Shit.
answer: Guess which came first. I should've known better than to think that a service station in the sticks would be open at this hour, but it wasn't like I had a lot of choices. What the hell. At least there'd be a diner opening in a couple of hours. I'd get some pie and coffee, and then I could worry about the gas.

question: Oh my god! I don't believe... oh my god...
answer: Mister, who are ya? my dog likes you, but that don't mean much, she likes skunks, too. Sweet n'stupid, that's why I keep her. Mister, you okay? You look wet. You in an accident or somethin'?

question: I... I don't know.
answer: You best come with me. Can ya walk?

question: I... yes, I think so.
answer: Come on, we'll have the Doc look you over.

question: My head hurts.
answer: I shouldn't be surprises. You smell like that was quite a night before you had there. Maggie! Let's go now! Name's Stanton Lawson. My ancestors founded this town.

question: Ancestors?
answer: Actually, my grandpap. But "ancestors" sounds better, don't it? Here.

question: I suppose. Thanks.
answer: You look familiar, fella. What's your name?

question: I'm... I... I honestly don't know. They all know you?
answer: 'Course they all know me. And I know all them. Town's got my name, don't it? Ernie Cole here just got himself elected mayor. Lost both his boys in the war. Kenny at Anzio and Willie at Normandy.

question: The war...
answer: Mabel over there at the diner lost her husband Max. Okinawa, I believe. All told, this little town gave sixty-two of its finest to the war. Seventeen of 'em at Normandy alone. More'n its share, I should say. Got us a letter from President Truman. City council commissioned a war memorial. Been sittin' in the basement of city hall these six years. Town never had the heart to put it up. Place just hasn't been the same since the war. You hungry, son?

question: Yes. Very.
answer: Got any money? Six bits. More'n enough to buy some breakfast. C'mon.

question: 'Mornin' Harry. Fine day, isn't it?
answer: Morning, Doc. Yes, yes it looks just fine.

question: Plenty to do today?
answer: Oh, yes, plenty. Plenty.

question: Any idea how you got here, son?
answer: No, sir.

question: Been drinkin' a bit, have we?
answer: I don't remember. I guess so. Smells like it. Tastes like it.

question: Well, you've been wet to the skin. You must've fallen in.
answer: I guess I did.

question: Lucky you got out, that water's got quite a pull, and it empties straight into the ocean. Here, one of mine.
answer: Thanks.

question: Do you remember if you were driving a car? Maybe you went over the bridge. No guard rail there, it's easy to do. It's happened before.
answer: It's possible. I just don't remember.

question: And you don't know your name or who you are, that right?
answer: I... no, I... I just can't...

question: It's okay, son. We just need to call you something. That's all. What is it?
answer: Call me... Ishmael?

question: Well, at least you remember "Moby Dick." Stanton found him by the wash. Not hurt too bad, but he took a nasty bump on the head and he can't remember who he is. We both think he looks familiar, but we can't place him. You bet. He'll be here. That's me and my daughter Adele. My pride and joy. Charms the fish right out of the lake, she does.
answer: She's very pretty.

question: Thanks. Well, Sheriff's on his way over, and maybe we can get to the bottom of who you are... ... sorry 'bout that, but you do look familiar to me.
answer: Wish I could say the same thing.

question: Cecil! Cecil, there's a young man in there...
answer: Lord love a duck, Harry, you wanna give me a heart attack right in front of the doctor's office?

question: Listen to me! The young man in there...
answer: Stan Lawson found him unconscious by the wash this morning, and I'm here to investigate, and if we find anything interesting, it'll be in the paper, so why don't you just...

question: Cecil, listen to me! It's Luke.
answer: No wallet, huh?

question: What I'm thinkin' is we got us one a'two things here. A mystery or a damn miracle. And by god I can't tell which. Boy, you say you have no idea who you are? That right?
answer: Yes.

question: You ever been in this town before, to your knowledge?
answer: No. But...

question: But what?
answer: Well, this place sorta reminds me of something.

question: What's that?
answer: "It's a Wonderful Life."

question: The Jimmy Stewart picture? I remember that one. Saw it over at the Bijou. So, you remember that, huh?
answer: "It's a Wonderful Life?"

question: Or the Bijou. Either one.
answer: I remember the picture... but I don't remember where I saw it.

question: Excuse me... what's your, um, your name?
answer: Harry, son. Harry.

question: And... what's my name again?
answer: Albert Lucas Trumbo. But you've been "Luke" since you were a baby.

question: Ah. Luke. Luke. I like it. How long have I been gone? How long?
answer: You never came back from the war. We were told you were missing and presumed dead.

question: When did I leave?
answer: You joined up one month to the day after Pearl Harbor. January seventh... nineteen forty-two. Nine and-a-half years ago.

question: Exactly how long has the Bijou been closed?
answer: Hmmmm... after you left, it was difficult, and then Lily -- that's your mother -- she took ill and died... we haven't shown a picture since forty-eight.

question: Why?
answer: Well, after the war, with so many of the town's boys killed, people around here didn't much feel like going to the movies, I guess. Some of 'em moved away -- Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Francisco. Wasn't much to keep 'em here, I expect. And now with this "television" thing -- people just aren't going out as much as they used to.

question: Didn't you have any help?
answer: Oh, I had Irene and Old Tim but they really couldn't help much. Broke their hearts when we closed up. Broke mine, too. But now that you're back, well, things will be different around here, that's for sure. C'mon, I'll show you where we live. The day you shipped out. That was a proud day for your mother and me. Last time you saw her. Last time I saw you. Till today. That's Lily. Your mother, rest her soul.

question: Mother. She's beautiful.
answer: Well, yes, that she was. She certainly made this place a home. Can I get you anything? I can put some coffee on or some... stands, looks down warmly at his son. Then, suddenly, he's seized by a thought. He turns and crosses to the window. When I woke up this morning, my son was dead. Now, I have my boy again. I have my boy again. 'Morning, Son. Sleep well? They couldn't wait to see you.

question: Who... are they?
answer: This is the staff of the Bijou.

question: Oh. What... what time is it?
answer: Six-thirty. I thought we'd get an early start. Oh, I'm sorry, they know you, but you don't... you need to be re- introduced. Luke, this is Mrs. Irene Terwilliger.

question: Bless.
answer: Thank you, Timothy. What do you suppose they're talking about?

question: Dunno. Boy's smart.
answer: Yes, he seems to be.

question: Um... Harry? Did I ever keep the books here?
answer: No, your mother did, then I did after she passed.

question: Well, I'm the first one to admit that I don't know anything about bookkeeping, but there are some very interesting things in here. "February 10, 1942. Picture 'Ball of Fire.'"
answer: Gary Cooper. And Barbara Stanwyck. Yowsa.

question: "Eight p.m. showtime, ninety-six admissions, receipts including concessions, $84.75... plus one fryer and two-dozen eggs."
answer: Yes?

question: "one fryer and two-dozen eggs?"
answer: Forty-two was a lean year around here. The war had just started... you were gone less than a month... and we were coming off a bit of a drought as I recall. Not everyone could ante up the price of a ticket, and a chicken's as good as money if you ask me. At that time, it meant a lot to the folks around here to be able to come to the pictures.

question: Yeah, I know, but poultry...?
answer: I know it's hard to believe, son, but this place, this little place this wasn't a theater then, this was a palace! Any man, woman, child, you, me, it didn't matter, you bought your ticket and you walked in and you... ... you were in a palace. It was like a dream. It was like heaven, like you died and went to a palace in heaven, that's what it was like. And spotless, too. Come with me!

question: Dad?
answer: Delly? In here. How'd it go?

question: Not as bad as I thought it would. I think I passed.
answer: That's my girl! Did you...?

question: No hiccups, which was good. Who wants an attorney who gets the hiccups when she gets nervous? "Your honor, I object!"
answer: I always told you, baby... ... it's all up here.

question: Dad? What is it?
answer: Well, it's...

question: Oh my god... who died?
answer: Drink slowly. From the other side of the glass.

question: I think it's worse now.
answer: That always used to work.

question: Yeah, well it's not everyday you get news like this. You're sure he's okay? Other than the bump on the head?
answer: Well...

question: Dad...
answer: He doesn't remember anything, Delly. Doesn't know how he got here, doesn't remember his father, the town, the Bijou, anyone...

question: ... including me. Right?
answer: I'm afraid not. He looked right at your picture without batting an eye. But it's probably temporary. He got all the way to Lawson, so he clearly knew who he was and what he was doing until he hit his head. I'm sure it'll all come back to him. It just takes a catalyst.

question: You mean, me?
answer: It's possible.

question: ... but I don't think I remember you. But I'll sure try. What.
answer: No, I... I just wondering where you've been all this time.

question: Me too.
answer: You look... different.

question: I do?
answer: Yeah, a little. I think you grew an inch or so. And you've lost weight.

question: I did? Huh!
answer: You can all go home, now. He's not going anywhere.

question: Go on home, folks. And thanks for the welcome. I'll be home in a little while, Harry. Don't wait up.
answer: You two have a lot of catching up to do, I guess.

question: You bet.
answer: Goodnight, son. 'Night, Delly.

question: There. We're alone.
answer: Then why do I feel like we're still being shadowed?

question: Well... where can we go?
answer: I know a place. Come on!

question: City hall?
answer: You must not remember anything. Come on. You first.

question: Why me?
answer: Be a gentleman. You have to help me down. When we were kids, my Dad was mayor, and you and me and a bunch of others used to come down here all the time. Of course, there was a lot more room before they stuck the memorial down here.

question: How'd they get it inside?
answer: Through the door. It comes apart. Your name's on here. See? Right here. "Albert Lucas Trumbo." And all the others. I knew them all. So did you. We went to school with most of them.

question: It doesn't seem right, this being down here. It ought to be where people can see it.
answer: After they commissioned it, no one could ever agree on where to put it. The Methodists wanted it in front of the Methodist Church, the Presbyterians wanted it in front of the Presbyterian Church, the city council wanted it in the lobby of City Hall. Everyone finally got tired of the fighting. So they stuck it down here.

question: So, you're really gonna be a lawyer?
answer: And why not?

question: Whoa.
answer: Sorry. You don't know how many times I've heard that. "A lady lawyer? Are you crazy?" Like a woman couldn't be as good a lawyer as a man. Or better, in fact.

question: Have you always wanted to be a lawyer?
answer: You... don't remember, but yes, ever since I was a little girl.

question: What did... what did I want to be?
answer: Oh, well... I guess you... in high school, you were a pretty good first baseman. And we were on the debate team together. But... I think you were gonna run the Bijou. You were brought up there, and you loved it so much. And I think you knew how much the town needed a place like that.

question: I just wish I could remember some of this. You don't have a boyfriend or anyone... you know... like that?
answer: Actually, I was married. For four years. But... well, we didn't fit together. I'm divorced now.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: No, it's okay. See, when two people belong together, the other person should be the... the key that unlocks the rest of you... I'm not making sense, am I?

question: No, you are. I know exactly what you mean. It's not that you're missing something. It's that the other person gives something to you... that you had all the time. You just didn't see it until they came along.
answer: Yeah...

question: We were in love... weren't we?
answer: Yes. Hic!

question: What was that?
answer: Nothing.

question: Do you have the...
answer: I'm fine. Really.

question: Were we going to get married?
answer: Eventually. We were going to be engaged... when you came back from overseas... ... but you had to go... serve your country... Hey... it worked.

question: Hey, fella. So you live here, too, huh? How come Harry didn't mention that? Um, Old Tim? Sorry, it's late. It's Luke. Can I come in?
answer: Found me.

question: Yeah. I hope you don't mind. I didn't know anyone lived here... well, besides Harry. And me.
answer: Not used to visitors. Sit.

question: So I guess this fellow belongs to you. What's his name?
answer: Cat.

question: Cat. That's simple. I like it. Hi, Cat.
answer: We thought you was dead, you know. It's okay that I live here?

question: Of course.
answer: Do you think I'll get me a new u-u uniform?

question: I'll do everything I can.
answer: T-t-thank you. Thank you. I... I always... I always wanted to wear my uniform from the Great War, but your daddy, he always said no, that's not an usher's u-u-uniform, that's an army uniform and the Bijou, she's not the army. They give me a medal, but I lost it in the h-h-hospital. I forget things sometimes. Since the w-w-war.

question: You smell gas?
answer: Don't smell nothin'. He must not be dead in here.

question: Jesus.
answer: Hey, it's the best way to tell. You think he's drunk somewhere?

question: Wouldn't blame him if he was.
answer: Well, his rent's past due and he said to call you in case of an emergency. He lose his job or somethin'?

question: What's his rent?
answer: Thirty a month.

question: Here's three months rent, and a ten spot for no more questions and to keep an eye on his place. Now, I need a moment alone.
answer: Huh?

question: Take a hike. Am-scray.
answer: Huh? Oh, sure. Just pull the door shut when you leave.

question: You say you know nothing about it. You say this, yet you offer no proof. How am I supposed to believe you? You do see that I'm busy, do you not? Tell them to come in. I'll have to call you back. I love you too, Mother.
answer: We've got a situation developing...

question: Will you take those goddamn hats off?
answer: We've got a situation developing out on the coast. Appleton's just been reported missing.

question: Oh, you mean the suit. Harry kept all my old clothes. Fits okay, but it's a little big.
answer: Oh...

question: I shouldn't have worn the suit.
answer: No... you were wearing that suit the last time we went out before...

question: Oh...
answer: ... and It's just... well, deja vu.

question: This is strange. Do you feel it?
answer: What?

question: We've done this before, so many times. The last time was so long ago, but it feels like yesterday.
answer: Oh.

question: You know, everyone's so excited about the Bijou re-opening...
answer: It's gonna cost over nine hundred dollars to open the place, Delly.

question: Nine hundred...
answer: Yeah, and needless to say, none of us has that kind of money lying around.

question: What about a loan? You could go to the bank...?
answer: A loan to a man who ran his business into the ground and his son who can't account for the last nine-and-a-half years of his life? Not likely.

question: Well, there's got to be a way...
answer: Have you got a cigarette?

question: When did you start smoking?
answer: I don't smoke?

question: You tried to once. It was pretty pitiful.
answer: Oh. They're not bad.

question: No, they're not. I'd say your investment was paying dividends.
answer: My what?

question: Back in '37, you heard Benny Goodman play for the first time, so you went out and got a used clarinet. You wanted nothing more than to be able to play like him. You tried hard, but it wasn't long before it was clear that Benny Goodman would never be looking over his shoulder. So you gave the clarinet to Spencer.
answer: Huh. That was nice of me.

question: You had a hidden agenda, though. See, when he was five or six, little Spence used to follow you around like a puppy. Bothered the hell out of you. But as soon as you gave him the clarinet...
answer: ... he started practicing, and he left me alone from then on.

question: Exactly. And he got good.
answer: No kidding.

question: Now, did you remember that, or...
answer: Nope. Just filling in the blanks.

question: I'm Alex. He's Charlie. Yessir, 'bout the prettiest thing we ever seen, ain't that right, Charlie?
answer: Thanks boys, ya flatter me no end.

question: Hey, Delly, what was that test you was outta town takin'?
answer: It's called the State Bar Exam.

question: How do you tell those two apart, anyway?
answer: Alex and Charlie? Simple. Alex is the smarter one.

question: That's... pretty frightening.
answer: Your dancing's very good.

question: Thanks.
answer: It never used to be. You were two left feet on the dance floor. Like pulling teeth to get you to do a little box step.

question: Luke, you probably don't remember me, Roscoe Fitts, I'm the grocer here in town.
answer: Good to meet you. Again.

question: Like Ernie said, we're all glad to have you back.
answer: Thanks.

question: And I hear you and Harry are planning on re-opening the Bijou.
answer: We're gonna try. Place needs a lot of work.

question: I can only imagine. You know, I spoke with your Dad last year about maybe taking the Bijou off his hands. I don't think he gave it very much thought.
answer: Well, he loves the place. It's his home.

question: Luke, I'm hopping you can help him see the reality of the situation. I'll come to the point. I want to buy the property, and I'm prepared to offer six-thousand dollars for it. And that's just for the property, mind you. If you want, I'll leave it to you and your father to dismantle and liquidate the building for whatever salvage value it has, and you keep those proceeds. I just want the land.
answer: That's... well, that's very generous, but if you've already got a store...?

question: The days of the storefront grocery are numbered. I plan on putting up a free-standing supermarket.
answer: A super market. Huh.

question: who looks up towards the projection booth.
answer: Beautiful, wasn't it?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, son, I wish I could've shown you more, but this is all that's left. Just this one reel that never got sent back from a picture we showed here a long time ago. Nineteen twenty-five, to be exact...

question: Dad, I...
answer: Ha!

question: ... what?
answer: You know, since you've been back, that's the first time you've called me "Dad." Luke... what time is it?

question: Six-thirty. I thought we'd get an early start.
answer: Thanks, Vera. Well, the chair notes the presence this morning of Luke and Harry Trumbo and the rest of the Bijou staff. Frankly, the chair notes the presence of just about anyone who ever finds their way into one of these meetings. G'moring, folks. I'm just guessing, but I bet it's not a sudden interest in Lawson politics that brings you all here.

question: Well, no... I wanted to thank you all for giving me such a nice welcome, and making me feel at home. But I... we're... actually here on business of a sort...
answer: I think we can make an exception here, Daley. All right, motion to hear the speaker out of order. Motion on the floor, discussion open, discussion closed, all those in favor signify by saying "aye." Opposed? Hearing no opposition, the motion is carried. Go ahead, son.

question: That was beautiful.
answer: I taught you that.

question: I can play the piano?
answer: Oh dear, yes. You were an excellent student, before all that clarinet nonsense. You loved Chopin. You used to call it "heaven music." "Teach me some heaven music," you used to say. Sit. Play with me.

question: No, I...
answer: Some of it might come back to you. That's good... that's good... Really, Luke! That's no way to treat Mr. Chopin!

question: Did you... did you...
answer: I'm here.

question: Did you... did you...
answer: Did I what?

question: Did you fix the damn film? It broke in the last reel.
answer: I know. Everyone went home. We offered them refunds.

question: Anybody take it?
answer: A few.

question: Vultures... I'm not happy about this, mind you, but if I have to go, at least I'm going in my own bed, the same bed my Lily died in, and... knowing that my son is alive. That's not too shabby, is it?
answer: You're not going anywhere, Harry.

question: Don't tell me, I know about these things. I've seen it before. It's all right. It's... all right. You're here. Oh, God, I love you, son.
answer: And I love you... Dad.

question: Oh, so... much... lighter...
answer: Sure. Your father said... that I would start to remember things.

question: Sure. Your father said... that I would start to remember things.
answer: What... do you remember?

question: Well... everything. It started coming back a couple of days ago. I remember everything now.
answer: I see...

question: Delly. I'm... I'm not... Harry wasn't my father. And I'm not... I'm not Luke.
answer: Oh... Oh, god, I knew! I knew! I knew from the start! I wanted you to be Luke! I wanted you to be alive! You're so much like him, you have no idea. No wonder everyone else accepted you! You don't know what you -- what Luke meant to this town, suddenly being alive! You don't know what this town lost! You just don't know... I knew you weren't Luke! And I tried not to fall in love with you! And... I don't even know your name! Oh, god...

question: I fell in love with you, too, Delly. Only now I don't know how I feel, about you or about anything. I only think I know how Luke would feel. Delly, shhhhhh...
answer: No... I can't... I have to... I can't...

question: Are you the sheriff?
answer: And I got the uniform to prove it.

question: I'm Special Agent Walter Saunders, this is Special Agent Steven Brett, FBI. May we have a word with you?
answer: Please, sit.

question: A couple of days ago, a county flood control maintenance crew pulled a car out of the Lawson Wash ocean outlet. They checked its registration, and when the owner was identified, they notified us.
answer: Well, that'd be Luke Trumbo. Looks like you boys've solved a little mystery we've had going on for a few months. What? No, there's got to be a...

question: I don't know what else to tell you. I wasn't hiding out. I hit my head and I didn't remember anything until a few days ago.
answer: Now that you remember who you are, were you planning on telling anyone your true identity?

question: I already have.
answer: Who?

question: My girlfriend. If she still is...
answer: Would that be Miss Sinclair?

question: Let's close up. Who's that?
answer: Hi.

question: Hi.
answer: I'm sure a lot of people down in L.A. are worried sick about you.

question: Yeah? I'm sure a lot more people down in L.A. want a piece of me. This Luke was a pretty good guy, wasn't he?
answer: Oh, yes. Yes, he was.

question: Well... let me tell you, I'm not Luke. I know who I am now, and you don't. And... I don't like me very much.
answer: You know, it's going to take me a while to get used to calling you Pete. Pete. Pete. It's a nice name.

question: Thanks, I like it. I think. Delly, I want to do the right thing.
answer: I believe you.

question: The truth is, I'm a lot of things, but communist isn't one of them.
answer: But if you only went to one meeting, why does anyone care? Besides, why should it even matter if you were a communist?

question: Come on, Delly, look at the country today. We're fighting communists in Korea, we're paranoid about the Russians, we've got this thing with the Rosenbergs and the atomic bomb... You think they want "suspected communists" entertaining the American public with party propaganda like, gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of the Sahara?"
answer: Forget about all that. You want to do the right thing? Then defend your name. If someone says something about you that's untrue, you have to stand up and say so. I know the law, and the law's on your side.

question: What about you, Delly?
answer: I am, too.

question: You'll stand by me?
answer: Whatever happens.

question: The FBI can't arrest you, because you haven't done anything wrong.
answer: Well, that's a relief. I understand they usually don't let that stop them.

question: However... you're gonna be subpoenaed to testify before the Un-American Activities Committee when they open hearings in Los Angeles. Now, if you play ball and tell them what they want to hear, they'll clear you.
answer: And I won't be a communist anymore.

question: Exactly.
answer: So it doesn't make any difference that I'm not one now, and have never been one.

question: Darling, don't kid yourself. We don't have a "democracy" in this country. The Declaration of Independence? The Constitution? These are pieces of paper with signatures on 'em. And you know what a piece of paper with a signature is? It's a contract. And you know what a contract is? Something that can be re-negotiated at any time. It just so happens that the House Un-American Activities Committee is re- negotiating the contract this time around. Next time, it might be the FBI. The time after that, it might be the President. But it'll always be someone. Count on it.
answer: That's not the country Luke fought for.

question: Lest we forget, Peter, your own military career was somewhat less illustrious than Luke's.
answer: It's wrong, Leo.

question: Peter, don't let that stop you all of a sudden. Here. When you're called, read this to them. Just tell the bastards what they want to hear, and we can all get on with our lives.
answer: You found him. This is a great honor. I'll treasure this always. Thank you. "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby renounce my membership in the American Communist Party, and by way of purging myself of my indiscretion, wish to provide the following names of fellow members to this committee, so that those persons may have the opportunity to do as I have done..." Jesus... Old Tim?

question: You found him. This is a great honor. I'll treasure this always. Thank you. "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby renounce my membership in the American Communist Party, and by way of purging myself of my indiscretion, wish to provide the following names of fellow members to this committee, so that those persons may have the opportunity to do as I have done..." Jesus... Old Tim?
answer: Can I... Can I t-t-talk to you?

question: Sure. Come on in. I was just packing. Please, sit.
answer: Thanks. They'll come back, you know. They'll all c-c-come back.

question: The customers? I don't know...
answer: They will. They w-w-will.

question: Tim, I have to tell you something.
answer: Oh.

question: It's about me.
answer: Oh.

question: I'm... I'm not Luke. Luke is dead. He died in the war. He's not coming back, and I'm not him. I don't even belong here. This whole thing started out as an accident, and that's all it is. An accident.
answer: Oh...

question: My name isn't Luke. It's Peter. Peter Appleton.
answer: Did you think I didn't kn-kn-know that?

question: I thought you...
answer: I know more than you give me c-c- credit, that's for sure. Don't you see, it don't m-m-matter who you are? All that matters is what you g-g-gave us. And you can't take that away now. You're wrong, Peter Appleton. You do belong here. You hafta give us back the B-B- Bijou.

question: You've got everything?
answer: Yeah. Except a chance in hell of coming out of this intact.

question: You'll be fine. No matter what Leo Kubelsky says, you've got a hundred and seventy-five years of American law on your side. Don't forget that.
answer: I wish you were coming with me.

question: And who's gonna run the projector until you get back? Mrs. Terwilliger?
answer: Maybe we could train Cat to run the projector. You know, a system of scratching posts, and gears, and levers...

question: Did you bring along something to read?
answer: Damn...

question: I didn't think so. Here. This is mine, you can borrow it. Not exactly light reading, I know. Believe it or not, I've read this since high school, and it got me all the way through law school. Besides, there's something in there that'll help you. You won't have to get very far, it's near the beginning.
answer: Delly... thanks, thank you. I'll take good care of this.

question: Just remember two things. First, the law is a living thing. It made us free and it keeps us free. Sometimes it gets twisted around by people for their own purposes. Sometimes it makes mistakes, sometimes big mistakes. But in the end, the law prevails for the just. Sometimes, it takes a while.
answer: Okay. What's the second thing?

question: The agenda for this morning's special session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities shows a number of witnesses, and I'd like to admonish those that are here to view the testimony of our first witness to keep order at all times, or this chamber will be closed. I'm referring especially to the ladies and gentlemen of the press. I hope that's clear. Call Peter Appleton. The witness will please stand and raise his right hand. Do you swear that the testimony you are about to give before this committee of the United States House of Representatives will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you god?
answer: I do.

question: Be seated and state your full name and place of residence for the record.
answer: Peter Kenneth Appleton. Hollywood, California.

question: The chair notes that you are appearing without the benefit of counsel today, Mr. Appleton. We certainly hope this means that you intend to be fully forthcoming with this committee?
answer: I'll do my best, Mr. Chairman.

question: Now, we're informed that you have a statement you'd like to read, is that correct?
answer: A statement?

question: Yes. A prepared statement.
answer: Um... no. I don't have a statement at this time.

question: Thank you Mr. Chairman, and thank you Mr. Appleton, for appearing today. Mr. Appleton, you mention that your home is Hollywood, California. But isn't it true that for the last several months, you've made your home in a town called Lawson, California?
answer: Sir, that is true.

question: Mr. Appleton, do you know an "Albert Lucas Trumbo?"
answer: Luke Trumbo? We never met. But I'd like to think I know him.

question: Is that because you were masquerading as Luke Trumbo while you were in Lawson?
answer: Mr. Clyde you're twisting things around. I wasn't masquerading. Luke Trumbo... Luke was a good man who gave his life for his country. I just... happen to look a little bit like him. That's all.

question: Yes, I see that Private Trumbo was reported missing in action and is presumed dead. I also see that you were posted stateside during the war. Fort Dix?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Anyone who reads the newspaper is quite familiar with your... "accident," Mr. Appleton. An accident which, conveniently, came hard upon your dismissal from United Pictures. Tell us, this "accident" of yours, are we given to understand that it affected your memory?
answer: Yes.

question: And what is the state of your memory now?
answer: I'm sorry, what was the question?

question: We... appreciate... your little note of levity, Mr. Appleton, but this is a very serious matter, and it merits your fullest attention. That state of your memory now, Mr. Appleton?
answer: Sir, are you referring to the fact that I was suffering from amnesia, and I've since recovered my memory?

question: I'm interested in knowing if you remember things you did in your past, or if they've been conveniently "blotted out" as a result of your "accident."
answer: Mr. Clyde, I remember everything.

question: Good. Good. Now, I hold in my hand a photostatic copy of the attendance roster for the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club" of the University of California, Los Angeles, dated October 11, 1935. A copy of this paper is before you, Mr. Appleton. Do you recognize it?
answer: Yes... yes, I do.

question: Referring to line thirty-seven of the document, does your printed name and signature appear there?
answer: Yes it does.

question: Mr. Appleton, please tell this committee what was the nature and purpose of the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club?"
answer: Mr. Clyde, do you want to know what I knew then, or do you want to know what I know now? They're two different things?

question: Start with what you knew then.
answer: Well, I'd direct the attention of counsel and committee to line thirty-six of the document, and the name printed and signed there.

question: We see it. For the record, it reads "Lucille Angstrom." What's the point of this?
answer: Well, that's what I knew then. Or who I knew, I should say. You see, I was trying to court Miss Angstrom. I went to the meeting to impress her.

question: Are you asking this committee to believe that you attended a meeting of a communist party front organization in order to impress a girl?
answer: Well, if you'd seen Miss Angstrom... You asked for the truth. That's the truth. I had no idea what the meeting was about. I just sat through it so I could be near her. I'm sure even a Majority Counsel like yourself is familiar with the concept of impressing a girl.

question: Mr. Appleton... Are you now, or have you ever been, a member of the communist party?
answer: No, sir.

question: Are you refuting this evidence and your previous testimony?
answer: I'm not refuting anything.

question: Yet you're contradicting yourself. You earlier testified that you attended a meeting of a communist party-run organization, yet you just said, under oath, that you were not now -- nor ever -- a member of the communist party.
answer: That's not a contradiction at all, sir. I went to the meeting, but I didn't go as a member.

question: Well, then, as what did you go?
answer: I'm a little hesitant to say.

question: Go ahead, Mr. Appleton.
answer: "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby..."

question: Mr. Appleton? Mr. Appleton?
answer: I... I need a drink of water.

question: Go ahead, son.
answer: Mr. Chairman... there's... another Amendment... that I'd like to invoke at this time, but it's not the Fifth Amendment. I wonder if you're familiar with it.

question: Mr. Appleton, you will...
answer: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."

question: I don't know... No, of course not... Look, fellas, I don't have anything to say...
answer: spins him around, and pushes him through the crowd toward the curb. Come on, kid. That was quite a show you gave them today. We shoulda sold tickets.

question: I'm not sorry for what I said.
answer: No, of course not, why should you be sorry? You're the new Peter Appleton. You exercised your rights as a solid citizen, first amendment, freedom of speech, all that. Very noble. Cigarette?

question: No thanks.
answer: When'd you quit smoking?

question: Luke didn't smoke.
answer: Oh, I see. But you're not Luke. You're Peter Appleton, the picture writer.

question: Not any more.
answer: Why not?

question: Leo, you were in there, you saw what I did. You think they're gonna let me write pictures? Hell, they're probably gonna throw my ass in jail.
answer: Not at all.

question: Besides, I don't even know if I want to write anymore.
answer: What, you're going to go back to that hick town and run the projector and marry the doctor's daughter? Peter, I'm an agent. I buy lunches and get deals made for guys like you. That's what I do. You're a writer. You write pictures. That's what you do. And trust me, you'll be back doing it again tomorrow morning.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Kid, you gave them what they wanted. This committee, it feeds on names. The more names, the better. But for some high-profile witnesses, like yourself, any name will do.

question: Leo, I didn't give them the names. I wouldn't do that.
answer: What, all of a sudden, "Lucille Angstrom" isn't a name?

question: Her name was right there in front of them. They gave it to me, I didn't give it to them.
answer: Well, that's not what they think.

question: Leo, she was... she was a girl I knew in college...
answer: You should keep track of your old school chums. Turns out she eventually joined the communist party. On top of which, she's Lucy Angstrom Hirschfeld now, and she happens to be a writer for "Studio One" on CBS.

question: Oh god, oh, god, no, I...
answer: So, our lawyers had a talk with the Committee's lawyers. That Elvin Clyde fella won't be too happy about it, but we cut a deal. They cleared you -- and they're gonna thank you publicly for your testimony purging yourself.

question: Thank me publicly? For what? For ruining this woman's life?
answer: Climb down off your cross. They already knew about her. She was subpoenaed six months ago! Who the hell do you think named you? All of which means... "Ashes To Ashes" is gonna be made, and you've got your job back. Congratulations, kid. Peter! Your hat! I was lookin' out for you all the time, kid. You did good. I'm real proud of you. Okay, let's go. Get some rest, kid!

question: is at the back of the crowd, working her way to the front. She rushes into Pete's arms, and they kiss. Another CHEER goes up.
answer: I see you got the telegram.

question: Pete, I'm so sorry about what they did to you. I didn't think you'd come back, I thought you'd want to write again...
answer: Dell, I can't write unless I'm happy, and I can't be happy unless I'm here -- and with you. This is me, Delly. Pete Appleton. And I love you!

question: And I love you, Pete!
answer: C'mon, Dell, we gotta go. Showtime in fifteen minutes.
